subject: lower processor job polling and handle queuing
commit_message:
lower processor job polling and handle queuing

when processing metrics which require updating very few
points/aggregates/series, the job may take very little time
(e.g less than 0.1s). additionally, each processing worker will grab
4 metrics every 1s. because of that, the worker may be idle -- since
it finished its 4 metrics -- even though there are other jobs on
queue.

this removes delay and blocks until job is on queue.

additionally, we process jobs in chunks. this creates the chunks
before queuing rather than on receiving end to minimise steps involved

commit_message:
Introduce socket timeout for a blocking socket

Monitor agent fails to monitor the switch once switch restarts.
socket.recv() is a blocked call (if timeout value is not passed)
due to which we cannot determine if the remote OVSDB server has died.
The remote OVSDB server sends echo requests every 4 seconds.
If there is no echo request on the socket for socket_timeout seconds
(by default socket_timeout value is 30 seconds), the agent can
safely assume that the connection with the remote OVSDB server is lost.
Better to retry by reopening the socket.

This changes this method signature from:

    find_migrate_repo(package=None, repo_name=None)

To just:

    find_repo(repo_name)

For the following reasons:

1. All of our migration repositories are in the same package now.

   extension-specific migration repositories. We don't have any reason
   to support that anymore.

2. This requires callers to specify the migration repo they are looking
   for, rather than magically getting the legacy to repo to continue
   supporting our old code without modification.

3. I dropped 'migrate' from the method name which may be confused with

Currently the 'update_available_resource' only update the allocations
records for the instances which are tracked by RT. Which leads to leak
allocations record in the DB. The cases for leaking:

allocation record on the source host leave in the DB.

the compute node back, the related allocations record can't be cleanup.

subject: Allow creating loadbalancer with network_id
commit_message:
Allow creating loadbalancer with network_id

Create loadbalancer accepts either a vip_subnet_id
or vip_network_id. If vip_network_id is provided the
vip port is created on that network using the default
neutron behavior. If neutron assigns multiple fixed ips,
an ipv4 addresses is chosen as the vip in preference to
ipv6 addresses.

-----

Who would use the feature?
LBaaS users on a network with multiple subnets

Why use the feature?
Large deployments may have many subnets to allocate
vip addresses. Many of these subnets might have
no addresses remaining to allocate. Creating a
loadbalancer by network selects a subnet with an
available address.

What is the exact usage for the feature?

POST /lbaas/loadbalancers
Host: lbaas-service.cloudX.com:8651
Content-Type: application/json
Accept: application/json
X-Auth-Token:887665443383838

{
    "loadbalancer": {
        "name": "loadbalancer1",
        "description": "simple lb",
        "tenant_id": "b7c1a69e88bf4b21a8148f787aef2081",
        "vip_network_id": "a3847aea-fa6d-45bc-9bce-03d4472d209d",
        "admin_state_up": true
    }
}

DocImpact: 2.0 API Create a loadbalancer attributes
APIImpact
Closes-Bug: #1465758
